conclusion: As shown in figure (a), four points A, B, M, and N in the same vertical plane are all at a distance of sqrt(2)L from point O. O is the midpoint of the horizontal line connecting A and B. M and N are on the perpendicular bisector of the line connecting A and B. Two point charges, each with a charge of Q (Q>0), are fixed at points A and B, respectively. An x-axis is established with O as the origin, and vertically downwards as the positive direction. If the electric potential at infinity is taken as zero, the variation of electric potential phi along ON with respect to position x is shown in figure (b). A small ball S_1 with a charge of Q (Q>0) falls vertically from point M with a certain initial kinetic energy, and passes through point N after a certain period. The magnitude of its acceleration a during its motion in the ON segment varies with position x as shown in figure (c). In the figures, g is the magnitude of the gravitational acceleration, and k is the electrostatic constant. Determine the magnitude of the electric force experienced by the small ball S_1 at point M.

The image consists of three parts: (a) shows two point charges at points A and B, with O as the midpoint of the horizontal line connecting A and B. M and N are on the perpendicular bisector. (b) displays the electric potential variation along the ON segment, indicating points with specific potentials. (c) illustrates the acceleration of a small ball with respect to position x, showing a variation with potential.

premise: O is the midpoint of AB, and M and N are on the perpendicular bisector, indicating symmetry.
In figure (b), the potential at point N is phi_N = kQ/(3L). Since phi varies linearly from point M to N.
conclusion: The potential at M is phi_M = 2kQ/(3L).

premise: In figure (c), the acceleration at point N is a_N = g, and at M it is a_M = 2g.
The electric force F can be found using the equation F = Q * dphi/dx. At point M, this becomes: F = Q * (2kQ/(3L) - kQ/(3L)) = Q^2k/L.
The force F is also related to the acceleration by F = ma, where m is the mass of the ball. At point M, a = 2g.
Equating the expressions for F from step 4 and step 5: Q^2k/L = m * 2g.
Solving for the electric force F: F = Q^2k/L = 2mg.
